Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Interaction between Spherical Particles and Biomembranes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research funds the collaborative efforts of researchers at University of California Irvine and University of California Los Angeles to study how nanoparticles cross the surfactant-decorated air-water barrier within the lungs. This project is cofunded by the Biomechanics and Mechanobiology program in the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation. To understand this transport of nanoparticles within the lung, the researchers plan to address the fundamental physics governing the interaction of small particles and monolayers, which in turn has broader implications for their interaction with biological membranes. The main focus of this study will be to understand the role of monolayer dynamics, e.g., the compression and expansion of the lung during breathing, and on particulate transport through the monolayer. This experimental approach would be developing a new experimental model combining dynamic Langmuir monolayer techniques 'expanding and compressing of a surfactant layer' with cellular culture models used in traditional static studies of the lung. In addition, new theories for nonequilibrium monolayer structure and dynamics, e.g. folding, will be developed as part of this project. The proposed teaching and training include interdisciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students in materials research, physics and biology, and they will be participating in the design and development of the new experimental and theoretical studies, and close collaboration with researchers at UCLA Center for Biological Physics.

The interaction of nano- and micron-scale particles with the air-water barrier in the lung has significant health impacts, some positive and some negative. On the negative side, small particles making up part of air pollution have a negative impact on health when they enter the bloodstream through the lung. On the positive side, a better understanding of how particles cross the lung barrier into the blood stream will allow for the creation of new aerosolized drugs that could be delivered without injections providing a range of health benefits. For example, this provides great benefit to diabetics and others who otherwise require frequent injections. To better understand how particles cross the lung barrier, one needs a model system that incorporates the compression and expansion of the lung that occurs during breathing. This award will support the work necessary to develop such an experimental system and to understand theoretically how particles cross the lung barrier. The research also provides for the training of graduate and undergraduate students in the interdisciplinary techniques at the boundaries of physics and biology, which is necessary for the next generation of researchers, and development of the scientific work force of the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project examined the mechanisms by which small particles on the surface of a Langmuir monolayer pass through that interface and into the water below.  A Langmuir monolayer forms at the air/water interface when small amphiphilic (soapy) molecules accumulate there in a single layer.  Such monolayers form on interior surface of the lung and are necessary for normal breathing.  The researchers showed that, under the correct dynamical conditions of cyclic expansion and compression of the monolayer (as occurs during breathing), particles that adhere to the monolayer can pass through this molecular barrier and into the watery subphase below it.   This process of particle translocation depends both on the size of the particles and speed with which the monolayer is compressed.  From several experiments, the researchers produced a “dynamical phase diagram” delineating which parameter regimes of compression speed and particle size allowed for particle translocation.   The researchers then developed a theoretical understanding of the fundamental processes by which this process occurs.

 

When the monolayer is compressed, it forms deep folds that plunge down into the watery subphase.  Such folds begin as long wavelength elastic instabilities, and, upon further compression, form a series of deep invaginations in which the two sides (or leaflets) of the fold come into contact like the pages of a book. The central theoretical outcome of this part of the project involved the investigation of the forces and morphology of these folds and how these properties depend on the presence of small particles and on the speed of folding. 

 

Using a combination of analytic theory and numerical simulations, the researchers made several advances. First, they showed that shape of monolayer fold is highly folding-rate dependent. This is because there are significant viscous forces acting on the fold as it plunges through the water.  At low folding rates, the folds take a shape expected by the balance of local bending energy and the gravitational energy associated with displacing the water around the fold upward. As the folding rate increases, the fold cannot plunge down through the water faster due to viscous drag so the monolayer piles up in humps on either side of the fold.  As a result, the amount of monolayer in contact between the two leaflets of the fold depends quite sensitively on the folding speed.

 

A second target of investigations involved understanding how the particles embedded in the monolayer affect the folds.  These particles in the experiments were used as fluorescent tracers to monitor the dynamic folding process. In the lung, there are various proteins embedded in the monolayer.  In addition, there can be a variety of one-hundred-nanometer to micron-scale particles introduced either intentionally for drug delivery through inhalation or unintentionally during the inhalation of airborne pollutants. We concluded that the particle translocation occurs when the monolayer is ripped by large tensile forces during the re-expansion phase.  This ripping is possible only if the particles behave as linkers, gluing the two leaflets of the fold together.  By preventing unfolding, the monolayer can then rip as it is expanded.

 

The researchers discovered the stability of the dynamically folding and unfolding monolayer depends sensitively on the folding rate due to the combination of three effects.  First, the shape of the fold and consequently the area of leaflet contact where linking can occur depends on folding speed.  Secondly, the force sustained by the linkers before rupture is itself rate dependent. Thirdly, the diffusion of linkers around the fold takes time.  If folding/unfolding happens sufficiently fast, the linkers cannot diffuse into the fold fast enough to strongly link the two leaflets of the monolayer.  The researchers also explored the effect of particle size.  These theoretical results agreed with the experimentally determined folding phase diagram. 

 

As a second aspect of the project we explored how thermal fluctuations (important for particles to link the two leaflets of the fold) interact with the geometry of curved elastic membranes.  These mathematical results predicted a particular spatial distribution of thermal undulations on red blood cells.  These predictions were quantitatively verified by our collaborators.

 

The broader impacts of this work include the potential for developing particles that can cross the lung surfactant barrier and get into lung tissue. This may influence the design of new drug delivery approaches.  The project also led the researchers to better understand how undulatory waves reflect and refract due to change in the underlying geometry of elastic membranes.  The implications of these results for understanding how cells use their membrane geometry to control thermal undulations remain to be explored. In addition, the research impacted the training of two postdoctoral scholars and two graduate students and contributed to the programs for STEM education in the broader Los Angeles community, including outreach to young scientists from traditionally underrepresented minority groups.
